div.ab: rāspīg: vid. Nērangs, Anklesaria, Kotwal and Boyd, Geldner.

Commentary.ab: Y11.9] Pirart del. and analyzes them as a collection of text in Old Avestan (cf. Parallels); Bartholomae, 1904 p. 1171: "Ein kabbalistisches Gemengsel aus meist gāϑischen Wörtern, die zum guten Teil in andrer als der ihnen zukommenden Bedeutung gebraucht sind".
Y11.9a məṇdāidiiāi] Kellens (Bartholomae), Hoffmann and Forssman; Geldner maṇdāidiiāi; Pirart məṇdaidiiāi (Kellens, 1984 p. 350 and Kellens and Pirart, 1991 p. 177).

Parallels.ab: Pirart, 2003 pp. 113-114: yō nō aēuuō ~ Y29.8 yə̄.nə̄ aēuuō; at̰ tē uiiē ~ Y34.11 at̰ tōi ubē; ϑrāiiōidiiāi = Y34.5 ϑrāiiōidiiāi; tūrahe ~ Y46.12 tūrahiiā; məṇdāidiiāi = Y44.8 məṇdāidiiāi; xšuuīdəm ~ Y29.7 xšuuīdəmcā; hapti (first part of haptāždiiāi) ~ Y31.22 haptī; āždiiāi (second part) = Y51.17 āždiiāi; nauua ~ Y35.6 nā.vā; dasme ~ Y28.11 dasəmē; yōi və̄ yaēϑma ~ Y28.11 yōi və̄ yōiϑəmā.

Nerangs.ab: rāspīg parāhōm pad dast ī hōy abar griftan pad gāh ī frabardārān barišn dast čahār angušt barsom dārišn bē gōwišn yō nō aēuuō at̰ tē uiiē ϑrāiiōidiiāi tūrahe maṇdāidiiāi xšuuīdəm haptāždiiāi nauua dasme yōi və̄ yaēϑma

"The rāspīg should take the parāhōm with the left hand and bring it to the place of the frabardarān. He has to hold his hand (at a distance of four finger of) the barsom. He has to say: yō. nō. aēuuō. at̰. tē. uiiē. ϑrāiiōidiiāi. tūrahe. maṇdāidiiāi. xšuuīdəm. haptāždiiāi. nauua. dasme. yōi. və̄. yaēϑma.."

rāspīg parāhōm pad dast ī hōy abar griftan pad gāh ī frabardārān barišn bē ō gāh ī xwēš pad war ī zōhrag dast čahār angušt barsom dārišn bē gōwišn yō nō aēuuō at̰ tē uiiē ϑrāiiōidiiāi tūrahe manḍāidiiāi xšuuīdəm haptāždiiāi nauua dasme yōi və̄ yaēϑma

"The rāspīg should take the parāhōm with the left hand and bring it to the place of the frabardarān, to its own place facing the zōhrag. He has to hold his hand (at a distance of four finger of) the barsom. He has to say: yō nō aēuuō at̰ tē uiiē ϑrāiiōidiiāi tūrahe maṇdāidiiāi xšuuīdəm haptāždiiāi nauua dasme yōi və̄ yaēϑma"

Quotations.ab: pad ẏō nō aēuuō at̰ te parāhōm pad war ī zōhrag barišn u-š ẏō nō aēuuō pad war ī zōhrag gōwišn ast kē ēdōn gōwēd ay ka andar rāh-ē be gōwēd ā šāyēd
"At ẏō nō aēuuō at̰ he has to bring the parāhōm next to the zōhrag. He has to recite ẏō nō aēuuō facing the zōhrag. There is one commentator who says: "If he recites it on the way, it is allowed."

ab.ab: "The chief priest, after reciting upto here, sits quietly. The assistant priest, without saying anything, after making his left hand pure, picking up the hom cup with that left hand from the top of the table, going near the fire, with the right hand, he puts on the ladle that one (piece of) wood (and) incense which has been kept on the second stone, he puts (it) on the fire and then coming towards the chief priest’s left side, putting the hom cup on the barsam holder, the assistant priest recites alone the below Avestan (text)"

"Before concluding st. 8, the rāspī purifies his left hand with water poured from the vaselike pot located next to the large basin of water. With his purified left hand he picks up the parāhōm cup, returns to his place, and while holding the cup before the fire, takes the last remaining set of sandalwood and frankincense (ēsm-bōy) from the stone block nearest the fire and offers it on a ladle to the fire. Returning the ladle to its tray, he walks around the south side of the fire to the ritual table and touches the parāshōm cup to the southern edge of the barsom wires. He recites st. 9 alone, directing his words to the zōt: "May this (the parāhōm) have ten-fold blessings on you." He pours a few drops of the parāhōm juice on the date-palm cord tied around the barsom, and hands the cup to the zōt, who takes it in his right hand."
